awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: FishLife: genealogy and traits of living and fossil vertebrates that never left the water
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop and apply a unified framework for studying the evolution of all fishes, including lampreys, sharks, and the coral reef, deep sea and freshwater fishes. This work will illuminate the genealogical relationships (phylogeny), evolutionary timing, and mechanisms for the origin and maintenance of the world's diversity of fishes, including the most important food and aquarium fishes. The project will contribute to community-driven scientific efforts, to student training, to web content and application development, and to public outreach. All fish specimens, specimen and DNA data, and analytical results obtained will be made publicly available through a dynamic and open structure that complies with established standards to facilitate wide accessibility to the broader scientific and non-scientific communities. High school, undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral student training are central activities for this project. Social media outreach and training will provide diverse professional development opportunities as well. A fish species identification application for smartphones based on image data (FishSnap) will be developed and made freely available to the public to allow accurate identification of selected groups of fishes. Outcomes of this project will form part of a new public exhibit at the National Museum of Natural History to highlight the value of specimen collections at natural history museums.

This integrative project will combine genomic, paleontological, anatomical, functional, ecological, and comparative approaches. The research team blends strengths in collections-based research on fishes, molecular and morphological phylogenetics, bioinformatics, and comparative analyses, allowing them to synthesize big data sets to resolve the phylogeny of all described fish species and conduct evolutionary analysis of key traits. Time-calibrated trees will be used to reveal diversification patterns of the major groups. Image analysis, morphometrics, and phenomic data will enable the discovery of evolutionary patterns in size, shape, and biomechanical function across thousands of species.

por.por_cntn:
This project is building a tree of life of all living and fossil fishes, revealing the course of evolutionary changes taking place during the last 400 million years to bring about the extraordinary diversity of fishes we see today. Ongoing work is based on extensive comparisons of DNA sequences from across the genomes of more than 5000 specimens, using advanced methods and developing new comparative approaches along the way. Detailed studies on select divisions of the fish tree that delimit emblematic groups such as snappers, seahorses, tunas, surgeonfishes, elephantfishes, and numerous perch-like families demonstrate the power of integrating evidence from genomic sequences with various other layers of data ?paleontological, anatomical, functional, ecological, geographical?to provide deeper insights into the evolutionary paths that shaped their diversity. Such studies demonstrate, for example, how the intricate relationship among biological properties and external factors gave rise to convergent evolution of anatomical features and to present-day biogeographic distributions. The challenging task of analyzing massive genomic datasets has resulted in the development of new analytical approaches published in the scientific literature or as software packages, such as a gene genealogy interrogation method, creating a new approach to handle phylogenetic uncertainty in comparative analysis, measuring and adjusting for missing data, developing a machine-learning approach to assess whether top competing tree topologies may reflect known sources of methodological error, and many more. A vast network of collaborators from many institutions in different countries established for this project is committed to extending this effort beyond the funding period. This group already trained over 20 graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, some of whom are already established academics. Dissemination of the results to date are in the form of two book chapters, over 15 peer-reviewed journal publications, and numerous presentations at scientific conferences. When the pandemic-restrictions lift at the Smithsonian Institution and staff/fellows are allowed back in the museum on a regular basis, we will be scheduling a series of "scientist is in" events in the osteology/evolution hall, the ocean hall, and Q?rius for FishLife investigators to further disseminate results.
